intro: Astragalus pseudohirsutus, commonly known as the hairy milkvetch, is a perennial legume native to the arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features compound leaves with small, hairy stipules. The plant produces yellow or orange flowers in racemate clusters, which bloom in the summer months. Its root system is extensive, allowing it to thrive in poor soils and withstand drought conditions. Astragalus pseudohirsutus plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing forage for wildlife.
